user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_bind:
```c
static int metal_uio_dev_bind(struct linux_device *ldev,
			      struct linux_driver *ldrv)
{
	struct sysfs_attribute *attr;
	int result;

	if (strcmp(ldev->sdev->driver_name, ldrv->drv_name) == 0)
		return 0;

	if (strcmp(ldev->sdev->driver_name, SYSFS_UNKNOWN) != 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_INFO, "device %s in use by driver %s\n",
			  ldev->dev_name, ldev->sdev->driver_name);
		return -EBUSY;
	}

	attr = sysfs_get_device_attr(ldev->sdev, "driver_override");
	if (!attr) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "device %s has no override\n",
			  ldev->dev_name);
		return -errno;
	}

	result = sysfs_write_attribute(attr, ldrv->drv_name,
				       strlen(ldrv->drv_name));
	if (result) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to set override on %s\n",
			  ldev->dev_name);
		return -errno;
	}
	ldev->override = attr;

	attr = sysfs_get_driver_attr(ldrv->sdrv, "bind");
	if (!attr) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "driver %s has no bind\n", ldrv->drv_name);
		return -ENOTSUP;
	}

	result = sysfs_write_attribute(attr, ldev->dev_name,
				       strlen(ldev->dev_name));
	if (result) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to bind %s to %s\n",
			  ldev->dev_name, ldrv->drv_name);
		return -errno;
	}

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "bound device %s to driver %s\n",
		  ldev->dev_name, ldrv->drv_name);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_uio_dev_bind:
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
...
struct linux_driver {
	const char		*drv_name;
	const char		*mod_name;
	const char		*cls_name;
	struct sysfs_driver	*sdrv;
	int			(*dev_open)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					    struct linux_device *ldev);
	void			(*dev_close)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					     struct linux_device *ldev);
	void			(*dev_irq_ack)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					     struct linux_device *ldev,
					     int irq);
	int			(*dev_dma_map)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
						struct linux_device *ldev,
						uint32_t dir,
						struct metal_sg *sg_in,
						int nents_in,
						struct metal_sg *sg_out);
	void			(*dev_dma_unmap)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
						struct linux_device *ldev,
						uint32_t dir,
						struct metal_sg *sg,
						int nents);
}
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "device %s has no override\n",
		  ldev->dev_name);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 1.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The call to metal_log uses the metal_log macro which is defined using GCC/Clang language extensions: a statement-expression ({ ... }) and the GNU variadic-comma elision token paste (##__VA_ARGS__). Both are explicit compiler extensions, so Rule 1.2 is violated.
